ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CRIMINAL LAW (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS) ACT
(Period of detention)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the maximum period of detention for a person held under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act; (b) whether a period of five years' detention of a suspect is adequate for the purpose of rehabilitation; and (c) whether he will consider, on humanitarian grounds, the plea

Column: 662

of a detainee with good conduct for an early release to go abroad for further study.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no stipulation in the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act of a maximum period of detention. But all detentions under the Act are for a period of 12 months initially. Orders of Detention can, however, be extended for periods not exceeding one year at a time. A Review Committee reviews all cases to assess whether a detainee should be released. The Committee takes into consideration the gravity of the criminal activities the detainee was involved in, his conduct in prison and his response to rehabilitation. As

Column: 663

soon as he is found to have been suitably rehabilitated, he is released from detention.

    It is difficult to specify what period of detention would be adequate for the purpose of rehabilitation. Each case will have to be considered on its merits. Generally, first offenders will be released earlier than hardened criminals.

    Education is part of the rehabilitation programme for the detainees who wish to study. Some of them have earned GCE 'O' and 'A' level certificates through studies during detention. If a detainee requests to be released early in order to pursue his studies abroad, his request will be considered by the Review Committee. So far, there has been one such request and it was granted.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. Would the Minister like to comment on this? His predecessor's predecessor at one time said that he never held any person under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act for more than three years.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I do not know under what circumstances my predecessor's predecessor made that statement. But the point is this. I would not like to make a general comment on this matter as it is quite clear in my answer to the Question that each case must be treated on its own merits. In other words, a first offender could be detained for a shorter period whereas a hardened criminal would be detained for a longer period. Of course, the length of detention would depend on the progress of the rehabilitation of the detainee.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, would the Hon. Minister also consider the plea of a detainee with good conduct for an early release to study further in Singapore?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said, we have facilities in the prison where a detainee can study in peace and quiet. Some of them have done so and have attained GCE 'O' and 'A' levels. If the Member for Whampoa is asking about further study in the university, we have no university facilities in

Column: 664

the prison, but if there is such a case we will consider it.

TAXI DRIVER LICENCES
(Tests)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture the reasons why applicants for taxi driver licences have been unable to take their test since 1977.

     The Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, as on 1st June, 1977 there were 11,397 applicants waiting for tests. In view of this backlog, the Ministry decided not to entertain any more new applications. Since then, 5,206 applicants were tested. Of these, 4,654 or 89% were successful and given licences.

    As on 1st January this year, we have a backlog of 6,191. The Registry of Vehicles will test all of them by the end of this year.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan: Sir, would the Hon. Minister explain why an English proficiency test is mandatory for taxi drivers?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, taxis serve not only the people working and living in Singapore but also tourists. Since the number of tourists is increasing year by year, in order to serve these people as well as the increasing number of English-speaking citizens, we thought it would be an asset and convenience if taxi drivers are able to speak a little bit of English. We do not expect a high standard of English from them but just enough for normal conversation.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Would the Minister consider giving exemption from this Proficiency test in certain cases, bearing in mind that not all taxi drivers serve tourists?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: It would be very difficult for a tourist to tell which taxi driver does or does not speak English. As I said, the standard of English required by the Registry of Vehicles is not high. The standard will be sufficient for normal daily conversation to find out the routes, the places that the passengers want to go, the charges and fare changes.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, surely the tourist would not spend too much time speaking English to a driver about the place. He only names the place, Orchard Road, for instance. Surely that should be within the comprehension of the taxi driver. What is the Minister's comment on this?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the answer is the same. As I said, the Registry of Vehicles is not demanding a very high standard of English. But if the Member has come across any particular case where a taxi driver has been put in an awkward situation where a high standard of English is demanded by the tester, then I would suggest that he brings it to my attention.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, would the Hon. Minister agree with me that it is not so much a question of ability to converse in simple English but recognition of street names, hotels and important places of interest. If such is the case, would he consider lowering the standard of English required for these taxi drivers?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the Member for Whampoa is again assuming that the standard required is fairly high.

PEOPLE'S PARK COMPLEX
(Complaint of floor vibration)


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he is aware of a complaint of floor vibration on the second storey of the People's Park Complex by a number of stall-holders; (b) if he is aware that, although the matter has been brought to the attention of the Director of Building Control Division since May 1978, no action has been taken to remedy the defect despite danger of the collapse of the second floor: and (c) if he will ascertain from the Director the outcome of his investigation which he had promised to convey to the complainants in his letter reference B/09/114/73 dated 25th September, 1978.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on 24th May, 1978, stallholders complained to

Column: 666

the Building Control Division (BCD) about the floor vibration. After inspecting the site on 31st May, one week after the complaint, the Building Control Division requested the developer of People's Park Complex to investigate and submit a report. In spite of reminders, it was only in late October 1978 that the developer informed BCD that the vibration was caused by the unbalanced cooling tower fans on the podium roof and that he had commissioned his engineering consultants to rectify the defect. He attributed the delay to problems encountered with his consultants.

    BCD inspected the site again in December 1978 and reminded the developer to speed up the works. In February 1979, the developer informed BCD that he had ordered spare parts from the United States as stocks were not available in Singapore. Repairs are expected to be completed by May 1979. These vibrations do not cause any danger to the occupants or to the building.

    Far from being inactive, the BCD has been pressing the developer and will continue to do so until the repairs are completed.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, why was all this communication between the Building Control Division and the developer not conveyed to the stallholders? They have been kept in the dark all this time.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the stallholders' complaint was about the vibration and BCD wanted to ascertain from the developer the actual position before replying. It is not good enough for the developer to say, "We will investigate it." I think the stallholders would not be happy with such a reply which is more or less not a reply.

     The Chairman: I have received a request that Head S, Ministry of Communications, and Head T, Ministry of Culture, be taken after all the other Ministries have been considered. I trust hon. Members will accept this rearrangement. This rearrangement is set out in Notice Paper No. 59 which is before Members.

    Head D -

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head D of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, I would, first of all, like to compliment you and your staff for taking the initiative to cause the various renovations to be effected

Column: 668

on Parliament House. Although the improvements can only be considered adequate and not lavish, as it should be, Members ought to be happy that we now have much better facilities to meet formally and informally. The library is now more presentable and soon we will not have to conduct Select Committee meetings in the very cramped and stuffy little room that served as the Committee Room for the past 20 years. To do justice to the more congenial working environment, parliamentarians should perhaps give consideration as to how we can conduct our business even more efficiently and effectively.

    There are two areas which I feel may be given careful review. These are (1) the Standing Orders, and (2) the Select Committees.

    Insofar as the Standing Orders are concerned, I am sure Members will agree that some of the existing provisions could be improved upon. For instance, as things stand at the moment, Question Time is limited to only one hour per sitting and Question Time is strictly for questions only. The relevant provision stipulates in no uncertain manner that "A question shall not be made the pretext for a debate". Sir, in this regard Members are only too familiar with your admonishment from time to time in your conscientious application of the Standing Orders. With due respect, Sir, as I see it, Question Time could be made more meaningful if more time is allowed and Members are permitted to put forward arguments in support of their questions. In short, what is the objection in allowing a question to develop into a debate. This is one example of what we could do with our existing Standing Orders.

    On Committees, it is time to re-examine the continued effectiveness of the various standing Committees of Parliament in the light of changed circumstances. We inherited from the British the Committee system which is basically a good system. However, owing to the lack of modifications and adaptations to meet the changing needs of our own particular environment over the years, I submit that we have only made very limited use of the system. Although the Estimates Committee and the Public Accounts Committee

Column: 669

have endeavoured to make their presence felt over the years, the objects, the rules and the guidelines regulating the conduct of business of the two Committees are somewhat vague and largely, in my view, outdated by changes in Government administration. Members appointed to the Estimates Committee have often felt uncertain over the exact nature of the Committee's functions. The line of demarcation between the work of the Public Accounts Committee and that of the Estimates Committee is also somewhat blur.

    In the British Parliament the Estimates Committee has long since disappeared and it has been replaced by a Committee known as the Expenditure Committee. Even this, I believe, will soon give way to more radical changes. I am not suggesting that we should follow blindly developments at Westminster as events in recent years have cast doubts over the effectiveness of the sort of parliamentary system operating at Westminster as one that is able to provide and ensure political stability in a country. What I have in mind, Sir, is the need for us to continue to evolve and refine our own system to meet the challenge of the fast changing circumstances so that we, as Parliamentarians, would be able to discharge our duty to the best of our ability in serving our people.

     The Minister for Law and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I have to inform the hon. Member, with regret, that he will not have the honour of the Prime Minister replying to him. The Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

    Sir, may I join the hon. Member in thanking you for improving the facilities within this House and outside, in the Annex. This was long overdue. It took you some time to convince the Ministry of Finance, but you have done so.

    The next point, Sir, is the Standing Orders which seem to bug not only Members on the other side of the House but even my own colleagues. Our Standing Orders were first

Column: 670

introduced on 1st January, 1960, and amended pursuant to several resolutions on May 1961, July 1962, June 1964, and November 1970, as stated in this Reprint dated 5th November, 1970. Our Standing Orders have thus been amended and refined from time to time. But I must remind Members again that these Standing Orders were drafted when we had an Opposition, and it was in fairness primarily to the Opposition, that these Standing Orders were drafted. We have not had an Opposition since 1966 when Members of the Barisan Sosialis left this House. Since then we have been returned unopposed and we have had it our way all these years.

    The Standing Orders are flexible. They are elastic. With your consent, Sir, and with the general assent of the House, we can do practically anything here. But do we want to write too much flexibility into our Standing Orders? What happens when the Opposition returns to this House? Do we go back to this Reprint?

    Members must realise that, under our system of Government, Parliament is supreme. We enact the laws. We can enact any law in this House. Members opposite are the elected representatives of the people, and since they belong to one party, our Party, they are absolutely supreme here. There is no one to take them on. So we have got to be careful. If we do what we like in this House, then one of these days we might have to pay for it. One of you MPs might lose your seat. So we have got to tread very carefully. As I have said, these Standing Orders have withstood the test of time, from 1960 up till today. So what are you grumbling about?

    Now, Question Time. What is Question Time? Question Time means what it says. You ask the questions, we give the answers. You pop a supplementary question at us, we try to reply. But now you want a full debate. The procedure now is that Question Time goes on for one hour. If you want a debate, there are many other opportunities for a debate. You are debating on the Budget today. You have Bills to debate on. Ministers move Motions. You Back-benchers can do

Column: 671

the same. At the end of the day you can seize the last half hour for an Adjournment debate and the Minister will have to reply. Hence, the reason for Question Time. If we allow it to develop into a full debate, then we might be here till 6 o'clock, judging from the number of supplementary questions that are asked of one Minister.

    I am not with the Member for Jalan Kayu when he proposes that we remove the restrictions which have been put in. He calls them restrictions. I say Standing Orders - Rules of procedure. It is just like the referee at the Stadium in Kallang. He blows his whistle when someone is off-side or does not play according to the rules of the game. You, Sir, call us to order when we get out of order. I think that is the way it should be. If he wants a free-for-all for Members, Parliament will, I think, degenerate and one day collapse.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I just interrupt here? I do not think I used the word "restrictions" at all. I do not think I used the expression "free-for-all" either.

     Mr Barker: I was not suggesting that the Member did. But impliedly, when he speaks of giving Members a freer rein during Question Time, one gets the impression that he wants to remove these restrictions. But I am sure the Member for Jalan Kayu would be the last in this House to ask for a free-for-all.

    As for the Committees, Sir, I agree with the Member that something should be done about the Estimates Committee and the Public Accounts Committee. What should be done, I do not know, because I have not been on these Committees. But the Member himself has chaired the Estimates Committee for several years. He has also chaired the Public Accounts Committee, which is the watchdog on Government spending. There is no clear division, although it has been spelt out in the Standing Orders, between what the Public Accounts Committee should do and what the Estimates Committee should do. But in thanking him for his comments on these two Committees, I would ask him, as the Member has the most experience in

Column: 672

these Committees, to make proposals which this House will give consideration to.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, I certainly do not expect this debate to end up as another one of those passing-the-buck sessions. I find the Hon. Minister's explanation not unsatisfactory though, but he seems to convey the impression that the Standing Orders are meant to frustrate the Opposition in this House. Surely that is not the case.

     Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not say "frustrate". I said, "in fairness to the Opposition".

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, in view of that clarification, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

3.00 p.m.

    Head I -

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head I be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code IE-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Governing a country is a serious affair. It cannot be done, as some feeble-minded people think it can, by merely having an Opposition in Parliament or in always having to make all people happy all the time. There are too many problems, hard and difficult problems, which can only be solved through hard and difficult ways, even bitter ones. And we have learnt that this must be so if we are to be what we are now and to remain adequately prosperous and stable.

    What we do as a Government, what we offer our citizens are made on the basis of the common but unpopular word called "policy". Policies indeed are the instruments by which taxes are made and new laws introduced. The shirts we buy, the cheap food we eat in hawker stalls, the clean environment, the

Column: 673

type of education our children get, the things the Police do, the stability we enjoy - all these are the by-products of policies. They have such an awesome influence on our day-to-day life that we must ensure that policy making and policy implementation in the Government are done with the best possible prospect of success and will indeed render us that degree of prosperity we could have.

    Who are the people who formulate policies, get them approved, implement them, and review them as to whether the results achieved are what the policies have been designed to achieve? No doubt the Prime Minister, his Cabinet colleagues, other political leaders and we Members of Parliament are part of this policy making team. There are also others from the trade unions, private sector or non-profit sectors, select individuals, whose views and support are sought and valued for this difficult process of policy making and implementation.

    But there is yet a group of people who are called by the unpretentious and unglamourous term "Administrative Officers". These are the people I am referring to in my amendment for this subhead. They can be Permanent Secretaries, Deputy Secretaries, Principal Assistant Secretaries, Assistant Secretaries or the junior Administrative Assistants. As a group, they are the people who are the first audience to Ministers' wishes and directives. They are the people who translate Ministers' wishes and views into all types of policy instruments. Of course, the best example is the Cabinet paper. The Cabinet paper in our Government system is the key instrument by which the Minister seeks to convince his Cabinet colleagues on what his Ministry wants to do, why it has to do it, how it is to be implemented, and what benefits can accrue from the programmes which are to be implemented from the policies.

    The style or method of policy making places the Administrative Officers in a very strategic position in so far as policy making and policy implementation are concerned.

Column: 674

The criticality of their position is magnified by the compactness of our society, our highly organised habit of doing things and the strongly elitist mode of our organisation.

    For these reasons, Sir, I am of the view that the Personnel Management Programme under the Prime Minister's Office will be one of the most important programmes in the Government, and the failure or success of this programme will largely determine the failure or success of our effort in building up a strong group of able, loyal and dedicated administrators, men and women with high character and integrity.

    We have been very fortunate to have acquired and built up sufficient strength in the Administrative Service and, therefore, the civil service. We have an efficient official language, English. We have good civil service traditions acquired from the British traditions which ensure stability and continuity, and we are freed by the unsettling effects of the "spoils systems" form of government. Our administrative and political cultures have also trained us to be unfettered by rigid ideologies. We are flexible and we are free to select what is best in the field of management, organisation and policy making, irrespective of the ideological sources or political constraints. We operate by merit and we have made our system a responsive system.

    In the area of administration in the civil service, and through the merit principle, we have been able to select the best brains and we can continue to do so as we have dismantled the previous exclusive policies in establishment of government where it once insisted that Administrative Officers must be a separate service closed to others from the other services. Now, officers from the engineering service and other departmental grades can join the Administrative Service and they can take up key positions. This is as it must be and it must be on the basis of merit and ability to give maximum contributions.

    For all these reasons, it is important for us to ensure that we attract the best to the Administrative Service and retain them. Most

Column: 675

importantly, we must allow them to see, understand and feel strongly to remain in the service to render their best.

    The easier way is to improve conditions of service like pay, status, benefits, and so on. Maybe there is a need for this because it is quite ridiculous to see two classmates - one joining the Administrative Service and having to shoulder onerous responsibilities but does not enjoy glamour, and the other joining the private sector who also has responsibilities, but enjoying much more glamour and much more pay.

    Decent working conditions and other benefits are actually entitlements to be expected, especially if the officer has the merit and he does work for the pay. But these monetary rewards have limits. This is so because I see the fine distinction between "dissatisfaction" and "satisfaction". To me, these are two concepts, operating on two different levels and are concerned with two different ranges of man's needs.

    Removing dissatisfaction cannot be deemed as incentives to greater satisfaction. What appears more critical to me is the rewarding nature of work itself; the privilege of being given the task of solving major problems, the opportunity to make meaningful contributions on substantive matters which are more crucial to larger numbers of people, the rare opportunity to feel that one has given one's best in the making of good policies, in making sure that the policies work and in seeing that so many people in our society are benefitting from the policies one has initiated. To me, Sir, this is the best reward that an Administrative officer can hope for and must strive to get. Such a desirable situation will result only if we have Administrative officers who not only have brains but also have character, depth of feeling and strength of commitment to help others in making Government work so that society will benefit. It also needs the infrastructures, the methods, the instruments and the understanding to build up this type of Administrative officers.

    I have, in April 1976, before I was given the privilege to be a Member of this presti-

Column: 676

gious House, been given the opportunity to be a drafter of a report which reads "The Singapore Civil Service, Projected and Actual" and this report is incorporated in a larger report entitled "The Singapore Civil Service - A Critical Appraisal".

    In that report, I have urged that central agencies like the Prime Minister's Office should explore and institutionalise the greater use of "special task force" which is multi-disciplinary and which comprises highly skilled administrators to tackle problems faced by Ministries.

    The primary function of such a task force should be to undertake in-depth reviews of special problem areas and to develop within the Ministry concerned the core essential resources, procedures and practices which will cause and facilitate the continual improvements of policies and services rendered by the Ministries concerned.

    I agree with him on the important role administrative officers play in the Government and the calibre of officers we should have.

    The Government has given due consideration to some of the recommendations made in the report which the Hon. Member mentioned. An example is the concept of using a special task force to tackle problems faced by Ministries. Hon. This report is expected to be ready by 16th March.

3.15 p.m.

    The Member for Kampong Kembangan has given a detailed account of the importance of the Administrative Service. Its members occupy critical positions in the Ministries and departments of the Government. They help the political leadership in formulating, reviewing and implementing policies. They therefore constitute the leadership in the Civil Service. Advice and assistance from the Administrative Service are indispensable to the political leadership. Appointment to the Service requires at least a good honours degree. This minimum entry requirement ensures that only officers of calibre are recruited. The Member remarked about the imbalance in rewards received by talented officers in the public service and those in the private sector.
